attributes.title: Sharing Fake News in Social Media: A List Experiment

q1.value: Sharing Fake News in Social Media: A List Experiment

q2.value: Alessandro Freire | Mathieu Turgeon | Carlos Oliveira | Ryan Lloyd

q5.value: Funding from Facebook Integrity Foundational Research Award.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: We will use a list experiment (Blair and Imai, 2012; Corstange, 2009) to measure the proportion of social media (Facebook, Whatsapp, Twitter and Instagram) users who intentionally share fake news in Brazil. Our data will come from a survey experiment conducted with 8,000 respondents recruited by the online survey firm Netquest. Given the potential sensitivity of the question regarding the intentional sharing of false information, our approach reduces social desirability bias by giving respondents in the treatment group more privacy when answering the question. Our sample will be comprised of Brazilian social media users aged 18 or older. By comparing the mean number of items chosen in the control and treatment lists, we will obtain an unbiased estimate of the population that intentionally shares false information in social media. Our sample will be randomly divided into three groups. The first group will directly answer four non-sensitive questions and one sensitive question (intentionally sharing fake news in social media), as is conventionally done in surveys. The second group will receive a control list with 4 non-sensitive items and will be asked to indicate the number of items corresponding to things they have already done on social media. The third group will receive a treatment list with the same four non-sensitive items from the control list plus the sensitive item of interest (intentionally sharing fake news). They will also be asked to indicate only the number of items corresponding to things they have already done in social media.

q16.value: • H1: The estimated proportion of respondents reporting having shared fake news on social media, as obtained from the list experiment, should be significantly higher than the proportion of respondents reporting having done so in the direct question (social desirability effect). • H2: Partisan respondents should be more likely to have intentionally shared fake news than non-partisans. • H3: Anti-partisan respondents should be more likely to have intentionally shared fake news than non-partisans. • H4: Politically knowledgeable respondents should be more likely to have intentionally shared fake news than those who do not know as much about politics.

q17.value: Our hypotheses will be tested using one-tailed t-tests with a threshold for statistical significance at p < .05. We will use the difference-in-means estimator to measure the social desirability bias associated with the act of sharing fake news in social media and the maximum likelihood estimator (Blair and Imai, 2012) for multivariate analyses of the list experiment. The complete wording of the direct question and list experiment can be found in the attached document.

q27.value: The survey-experiment will be conducted by the online survey firm Netquest.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The purpose of this study is to examine whether and how humiliation affects individual preferences for international conflict. My previous research suggests that humiliation increases an individual’s preference for conflict by decreasing their sensitivity to the cost of conflict. This study will examine this with an incentivized game where respondents face monetary costs to choosing to initiate conflict.

q16.value: 1. Humiliated Respondents will be more likely to choose attack in all conditions 2. Humiliated Respondents will be more likely to choose attack when the cost of war is high, regardless of whether they are the first or second mover. 3. Humiliated Respondents will be more likely to choose attack when the cost of war is high and they are the first mover. 4. The effect of humiliation on the probability of choosing attack will decay as the number of rounds after the essay treatment increases.

q17.value: The experiment will be conducted in the University of Wisconsin--Madison BRITE Lab. Each hypothesis will be examined both within and between subjects. Please see pre- analysis plan for full details.

attributes.title: Returnees From the Diaspora in Post-Conflict Politics

q1.value: Returnees From the Diaspora in Post-Conflict Politics

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: When intrastate war ends, a central task for local authorities, and international actors involved in state building is to create, or re-build, a legitimate government. Post-conflict countries generally suffer from a severe “brain drain” and thus a lack of qualified individuals, both in the public service and other domains in society. International donors have increasingly viewed diaspora returnees as a solution to remedy such brain drains, but at the same time avoid employing external actors who might be perceived as alien and neo-colonial and thereby harm local legitimacy. Several diaspora return programmes”^1 have been established by international agencies with the objective to enable capacity building in state institutions in post-conflict countries. In some places, such as Afghanistan, international actors have placed returnees from the diaspora in top-positions in the government (Turner 2008). In Liberia, the UNDP supported the Liberia Emergency Capacity Building Support (LECBS)^2 project through which 16 cabinet ministers and the head of the Liberia National Police was recruited from the diaspora (Friedman 2012). Despite that many post-conflict government are filled with returnees from the diaspora and international actors openly support these recruitments, we have limited knowledge about how local populations view these individuals. Scant qualitative evidence from post-conflict contexts suggests that the diaspora identity may be used against returnees from the diaspora, especially when returnees take on top positions in governments. The relationship between locals and diaspora returnees is often characterized by an element of mistrust and questions about loyalty (Sánchez Villa, 2011:10, De Carvalho et al 2011:20, Republic of Liberia 2008:52f). Accordingly the position of the diaspora in their countries of origin is often heatedly debated among elites. This is particularly true in post-conflict settings. Whom that should have the right to represent the state at the highest level and be in control of the state’s resources can be seen as the acid test of who should be included in the political community of a democracy. But to what extent the diaspora background by government officials are perceived as an identity of importance, and in that case if it is affecting the legitimacy of the government have not been systematically investigated. We know very little about the value citizens in post-conflict states devote to being a “local” actor and how they interpret government officials’ different background characteristics. Therefore, the aim of this study is to improve our understanding of how local populations view returnees from the diaspora in governments and how this relates to the legitimacy of the government overall. The research question guiding this article is as follows: - How does high presence of diaspora returnees in post-conflict cabinets affect the legitimacy of the government? ^1: Several return programmes have been implemented by the World Bank, the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), International Organization for Migration and a number of governments, such as the Netherlands and Sweden. (IOM, 2015). ^2: President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf reached out to the UNDP and claimed that recruitment from the diaspora was necessary since Liberia suffered from a brain drain and most of the individuals with necessary capacity to be part of the government were living outside of Liberia (Johnson Sirleaf).

q16.value: H1: On average, being presented with a cabinet with a high share of returnee ministers will depress the extent to which citizens view the government as legitimate. H2: On average, when returnee ministers are presented as to have an “escape route” to the United States the negative effect of diaspora ministers on governments legitimacy is larger than when ministers are not presented as having an “escape route” to the United States. H3: On average, a government with a high degree of returnee ministers will be perceived as representing the Liberian population/the individual respondent to a lower degree than governments including few returnee ministers. H4: On average, a government with a higher degree of returnee ministers will be perceived as less patriotic/loyal to the interests of Liberia than a government including few returnee ministers. H5: On average, a government with a higher degree of returnee ministers with an escape route to the US will be perceived as more likely to engage in corruption and less likely to be brought to justice in Liberia if engaging in unlawful behaviour.

q17.value: This research question will be investigated with the use of a vignette survey experiment in the context of post-conflict Liberia.

q24.value: The Swedish Ethical Review Authority (Dnr: 2019-00236) and the University of Liberia-Pacific Institute for Research & Evaluation Institutional Review Board (UL-PIRE IRB) (Assurance # FWA00004982).

q29.value: Researchers, as in the enumerators conducting the interview, receives remuneration from the Khana Group.

attributes.title: Support for militarism under public versus private signals about mass victimization: the case of Armenia

q1.value: Support for militarism under public versus private signals about mass victimization: the case of Armenia

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Can events from the past shape policy preferences in the present? We study the case of Armenia, where a large proportion of population lost relatives in the genocide of 1915-23. Do those whose families suffered from violence differ in terms of their policy preferences from those that did not? We hypothesize that historic victimization goes along with an increased support for a strong and ethnically homogeneous state, an emphasis on collective security rather than individual liberty, and stronger support for the military. We also ask whether this support translates into a preference for an aggressive foreign policy, revenge, and ambition of re-establishing historical justice. Overall, we expect to see fairly high levels of support for military aggression, but expect this affect to be driven by those not victimized. Instead, we expect historical victims to favor reconciliation with their former enemies, and to reject all forms of offensive use of violence. We thus distinguish individuals with a profoundly personal family history of the genocide, from those who became aware of the genocide from schoolbooks, the media and campaigns devoted to the 100th anniversary of the genocide. We refer to the sample with personal family history, as the sample with a “private signal” about the genocide, while those who learned it from school or media, as the sample with a “public signal.”

q16.value: Hypothesis GandM 1: We hypothesize that the “primed” subsample should have a higher percentage of tax devoted to the military. Hypothesis GandM 2: Those who receive a private signal about the history of genocide are more likely to have defensive motives. Hypothesis GandM 3: Those who receive a private signal about the history of genocide are less likely to have aggressive motives.

q17.value: Most hypotheses are tested straightforwardly using OLS or Probit regressions of the variable of interest on the regressor of interest and the number of controls (individual characteristics). The detailed description of the way variables are constructed and which regression are planned to be run available in PAP.

attributes.title: Security, Economic Performance, and Popular Support for Democracy: The Case of Mexico

q1.value: Security, Economic Performance, and Popular Support for Democracy: The Case of Mexico

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: An increasing number of studies have shown that government performance changes how strongly citizens support and are satisfied with democracy. Results so far have pointed to the role of political and economic performance and its impact on citizen confidence in government institutions and democratic support. Given that today 43 out of the 50 most murderous cities in the world are in Latin America (The Economist 2017), that close to 65% of Latin Americans feel poorly protected against crime (Latinobarometro 2015), and that up to 15% believe that under some circumstances an authoritarian government is preferable to a democratic one (Latinobarometro 2015) in this study, we will embed two survey experiments in an omnibus survey in Mexico to test whether deficiencies in security provision in Latin America can persuade citizens to forego key democratic norms and values in order to feel safe again, and how the effect compares to deficiencies in economic performance.

q16.value: Our general hypothesis is that respondents who receive scenarios with poor physical security performance will be the most likely to accept deviations from liberal democracy, both at a system and a policy level. Conjoint Experiment H1: Both physical and economic security will increase the probability that respondents choose one scenario over the other. H1A: We expect to observe an interactive effect between physical and economic security with granting the executive more unilateral power. H1B: The effect of physical security will be larger than the effect of economic security. H1C: The difference in effects will be larger in regions where criminal violence is prevalent. H2: We expect respondents to strongly prefer the scenario they choose when facing a trade-off between a positive and a negative treatment Priming Experiment Question 1: H1: A larger percent of respondents who receive the negative security performance excerpt will support this policy compared to the other four groups. H1A: The difference in proportions will be largest in the more violent regions. Question 2: H1: We expect respondents who receive the positive economic and physical security treatments be less supportive of criticizing the government. H1A: The difference in proportions will be largest in the regions that are richer and non-violent. Question 3: H1: We expect there to be no difference in responses among the five groups Question 4: H1: A larger proportion of respondents in the groups that receive the negative physical and economic security performance excerpts will support this policy compared to the other three groups H1B: The difference in proportions will greater in regions that have either high violence and/or are poorer compared to the rest of the country. Question 5: H1: A larger proportion of respondents who receive the negative physical security performance excerpt will support this policy compared to the other four groups H1A: The difference in proportions will be largest in the more violent regions. Question 6 H1: A larger percent of respondents who receive the negative physical security performance excerpt will support this policy compared to the other four groups. H1A: The difference in proportions will be largest in the more violent regions. Question 7 H1: We expect there to be no difference in responses among the five groups As described above, we do expect to observe heterogeneous effects in a) regions that have higher violence levels b) regions that have low-income levels c) in the size of the effects in the policy versus system questions d) within the policy questions, those that correspond to rule of law and executive power. For the first experiment, our causal quantity of interest is the average marginal component effect (AMCE). For the second experiment, we will analyze each of the six outcomes separately. For each outcome, as well as an index that includes all outcomes, we are interested in a simple comparison of proportions and in the average treatment effect. For more detail, see the pre-analysis plan.

q17.value: We will embed two survey experiments in a nationally and regionally representative omnibus survey in Mexico that will be conducted on September 22, 2017. For the first experiment, we will present to survey respondents a choice based conjoint analysis in which they have to choose between two possible scenarios in Mexico. Each scenario was made up of five attributes: a positive or negative performance attribute (either economic or physical security), a positive or negative rule of law attribute, a positive or negative executive power attribute, a positive or negative freedom of press attribute, and a positive or negative freedom of speech attribute. For the second experiment, we ask survey respondents to read one of five possible analyses of the current situation in Mexico (one control and four treatments) and then ask them to answer seven questions that test their support for illiberal policies. These policies include the fate of members of criminal organizations; publishing articles criticizing the government; participating in protests; horizontal accountability; human rights; use of violence to ensure order; and, inclusive participation.

attributes.title: The effect of losing (repeatedly) in direct democratic decisions on loser’s consent

q1.value: The effect of losing (repeatedly) in direct democratic decisions on loser’s consent

q2.value: Anna Kern | Lala H. Muradova | Sofie Marien

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Various scholars, but also policy makers and activists have claimed that an increased involvement of citizens in the political decision-making process could serve as a remedy to counter the alleged loss of legitimacy of representative politics (Tormey, 2015). It has been argued that by involving citizens more directly in the decision-making process, a better congruence between citizens’ preferences and public policy can be achieved (Budge, 1996) and citizens’ consent can be fostered. However, the making of voting directly on policy issues is polarizing in nature and generates exclusion (Warren 2017). It seems therefore surprising that little is known about loser’s consent in direct democratic decision making. In the scope of representative democracy, loser’s consent has attracted much scholarly attention in the past decade. The existing literature has extensively documented that legitimacy perceptions differ significantly between electoral winners and losers (Linde and Ekman 2003). Nevertheless, this “legitimacy gap” is not considered problematic as long as there are relatively frequent alternations in power. Losing repeatedly, however, is claimed to deteriorate legitimacy perceptions, because the representative system fails continuously to turn certain groups of citizens (and their policy preferences) into winners (Anderson et al. 2005). Losing repeatedly arguably corresponds to an exclusion from the political power system (Kern and Kölln 2017; Lijphart, 1999). Despite this fairly large body of research on this “winner-loser gap”, it remains unclear whether such a gap can be found in direct-democratic procedures where citizens are directly deciding on policy issues. By focusing on losers consent in the making of direct democratic decisions, the aim of this study is therefore to 1) investigate whether such a “legitimacy gap” between winners and (repeated) losers can also be found after direct-democratic decision making and 2) to explore the nature of such a potential “legitimacy gap.”

q16.value: H1: Legitimacy beliefs of winners are stronger than legitimacy beliefs of losers after direct democratic decision-making. H2a: Legitimacy beliefs of occasional losers are stronger than legitimacy beliefs of repeated losers after several rounds of direct democratic decision-making. H2b: Legitimacy beliefs of consecutive losers are stronger than legitimacy beliefs of discontinuous losers after several rounds of direct democratic decision-making. H3: The gap between winners and losers is asymmetric, as losing hurts more than winning eases. H4: The effect of all types of losing is moderated by citizens’ degree of news consumption. The more aware they are of current political issues, the less credible they may find losing in the voting study.

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested via an online experiment. The online study consists of a survey. The survey has four parts. First, we will measure the baseline attitudes of the subjects with regards to political trust, satisfaction with democracy, political ideology and partisanship. Second, participants will vote on three specific policy issues. Third, participants are exposed to the treatment: we will announce – one by one – how the other participants of the experiment answered the three questions on the policy issues. We tell the subjects ‘a simple majority of people participating in this survey online have made a decision over this question and the decision is…’. Subjects are either informed that the mostly voted policy choice is consistent or inconsistent with their own decision. Although this part is manipulated and unreal, we randomly and independently assign this decision to participants. In other words, participants will be randomly assigned to the winners or the losers of the policy decision. After each announcement of the result we will ask some questions regarding participants’ decision acceptance and process perceptions. The same procedure is repeated for the other two policy decisions. Since the main aim behind this study is to measure how losing (repeatedly) affects citizens’ legitimacy perceptions with this exercise we want to introduce the sense of ‘losing’ and ‘winning’ among participants. But as we do not know beforehand whether a subject will ‘lose’ or ‘win’, i.e. the process is purely random, the only deception we use here is when the respondents are informed about the ‘results’ of the hypothetical voting. Citizens will be debriefed about it at the end of the study. Further, in the fourth part of the survey, participants will be asked to answer a set of questions, aimed at tapping in the effect of losing on their decisions to (a) leave the study; and (b) change the rules of the game. The third question will measure the state of the frustration the subject felt in finding out that the majority decision was inconsistent with his own decision. Since only one part of the subjects will be randomly assigned to ‘lose repeatedly’, some of these questions will be relevant to that sub-group only. Difference-in-means t-tests will be run to examine the main effects of losing occasionally, losing repeatedly and winning repeatedly on citizens’ legitimacy perceptions. Additionally, we will run CACE (Complier Average Causal Effect) analysis with 2SLS (two stage least squares) instrumental approach, with the correct answer to manipulation check question as compliance. For heterogeneous effects (e.g. H4), linear regression models with interaction effects will be conducted.

registration_responses.q1: The effect of losing (repeatedly) in direct democratic decisions on loser’s consent
registration_responses.q2: Anna Kern | Lala H. Muradova | Sofie Marien
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities
registration_responses.q15: Various scholars, but also policy makers and activists have claimed that an increased involvement of citizens in the political decision-making process could serve as a remedy to counter the alleged loss of legitimacy of representative politics (Tormey, 2015). It has been argued that by involving citizens more directly in the decision-making process, a better congruence between citizens’ preferences and public policy can be achieved (Budge, 1996) and citizens’ consent can be fostered. However, the making of voting directly on policy issues is polarizing in nature and generates exclusion (Warren 2017). It seems therefore surprising that little is known about loser’s consent in direct democratic decision making. In the scope of representative democracy, loser’s consent has attracted much scholarly attention in the past decade. The existing literature has extensively documented that legitimacy perceptions differ significantly between electoral winners and losers (Linde and Ekman 2003). Nevertheless, this “legitimacy gap” is not considered problematic as long as there are relatively frequent alternations in power. Losing repeatedly, however, is claimed to deteriorate legitimacy perceptions, because the representative system fails continuously to turn certain groups of citizens (and their policy preferences) into winners (Anderson et al. 2005). Losing repeatedly arguably corresponds to an exclusion from the political power system (Kern and Kölln 2017; Lijphart, 1999). Despite this fairly large body of research on this “winner-loser gap”, it remains unclear whether such a gap can be found in direct-democratic procedures where citizens are directly deciding on policy issues. By focusing on losers consent in the making of direct democratic decisions, the aim of this study is therefore to 1) investigate whether such a “legitimacy gap” between winners and (repeated) losers can also be found after direct-democratic decision making and 2) to explore the nature of such a potential “legitimacy gap.”
registration_responses.q16: H1: Legitimacy beliefs of winners are stronger than legitimacy beliefs of losers after direct democratic decision-making. H2a: Legitimacy beliefs of occasional losers are stronger than legitimacy beliefs of repeated losers after several rounds of direct democratic decision-making. H2b: Legitimacy beliefs of consecutive losers are stronger than legitimacy beliefs of discontinuous losers after several rounds of direct democratic decision-making. H3: The gap between winners and losers is asymmetric, as losing hurts more than winning eases. H4: The effect of all types of losing is moderated by citizens’ degree of news consumption. The more aware they are of current political issues, the less credible they may find losing in the voting study.
registration_responses.q17: The hypotheses will be tested via an online experiment. The online study consists of a survey. The survey has four parts. First, we will measure the baseline attitudes of the subjects with regards to political trust, satisfaction with democracy, political ideology and partisanship. Second, participants will vote on three specific policy issues. Third, participants are exposed to the treatment: we will announce – one by one – how the other participants of the experiment answered the three questions on the policy issues. We tell the subjects ‘a simple majority of people participating in this survey online have made a decision over this question and the decision is…’. Subjects are either informed that the mostly voted policy choice is consistent or inconsistent with their own decision. Although this part is manipulated and unreal, we randomly and independently assign this decision to participants. In other words, participants will be randomly assigned to the winners or the losers of the policy decision. After each announcement of the result we will ask some questions regarding participants’ decision acceptance and process perceptions. The same procedure is repeated for the other two policy decisions. Since the main aim behind this study is to measure how losing (repeatedly) affects citizens’ legitimacy perceptions with this exercise we want to introduce the sense of ‘losing’ and ‘winning’ among participants. But as we do not know beforehand whether a subject will ‘lose’ or ‘win’, i.e. the process is purely random, the only deception we use here is when the respondents are informed about the ‘results’ of the hypothetical voting. Citizens will be debriefed about it at the end of the study. Further, in the fourth part of the survey, participants will be asked to answer a set of questions, aimed at tapping in the effect of losing on their decisions to (a) leave the study; and (b) change the rules of the game. The third question will measure the state of the frustration the subject felt in finding out that the majority decision was inconsistent with his own decision. Since only one part of the subjects will be randomly assigned to ‘lose repeatedly’, some of these questions will be relevant to that sub-group only. Difference-in-means t-tests will be run to examine the main effects of losing occasionally, losing repeatedly and winning repeatedly on citizens’ legitimacy perceptions. Additionally, we will run CACE (Complier Average Causal Effect) analysis with 2SLS (two stage least squares) instrumental approach, with the correct answer to manipulation check question as compliance. For heterogeneous effects (e.g. H4), linear regression models with interaction effects will be conducted.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The main question motivating this study is whether states can match the legitimacy of working through a formal international organization by using informal coordination methods. Myriad research demonstrates that IGOs can confer legitimacy on the actions of states. This occurs both through domestic public opinion and by affecting a state’s international reputation in the rest of the world. However, past research has looked almost exclusively at the legitimacy of intervening through or with the approval of an international organization compared to doing so unilaterally, the legitimacy of the support of different types of organizations, and the questions of legality versus legitimacy when intervening with or without the approval of different IGOs.

q16.value: H1: Interventions conducted through contact groups will be viewed as just as legitimate as those conducted through formal IGOs. H2: Interventions conducted through contact groups will be viewed as more legitimate than interventions conducted through coalitions of the willing and unilateral intervention. H3: Interventions conducted through coalitions of the willing will be viewed as more legitimate than unilateral intervention and less legitimate than interventions conducted through contact groups or formal IGOs. H4: Interventions carried out through formal IGOs will be viewed as more legitimate than interventions carried out through coalitions of the willing and unilateral intervention. H5: Women, people with higher levels of education, and Democrats will be more likely to view interventions carried out through contact groups and formal IGOs as more legitimate than interventions carried out through coalitions of the willing and unilateral intervention, and the magnitude of the difference will be larger than for other groups. H6: Women and people with high levels of education will be more likely to view interventions carried out through contact groups as less legitimate than formal IGOs compared to other groups. H7: Individuals who agree with the statement “US military force should be used in many situations” are less likely to perceive a difference in legitimacy between different types of intervention and the magnitude of the differences that do exist will be smaller. H8: Individuals who agree with the statement “The US needs to play an active role in resolving conflicts around the world” are less likely to perceive a difference in legitimacy between different types of intervention, and the differences that do exist should be smaller in magnitude than or those who disagree with the statement. H9: Individuals who say that the US can trust other nations are more likely to view intervention through both contact groups and formal IGOs as more legitimate than intervention through coalitions of the willing or unilateral intervention, and the magnitude of the difference is likely to be larger. H10: Republicans and individuals with low international trust are less likely to support an intervention when they believe that it was carried out for humanitarian reasons.

q17.value: These hypotheses will be tested using OLS with and without controls, simple differences in means, and difference of means of sub-groups of the survey respondents.

However, past research has looked almost exclusively at the legitimacy of intervening through or with the approval of an international organization compared to doing so unilaterally, the legitimacy of the support of different types of organizations, and the questions of legality versus legitimacy when intervening with or without the approval of different IGOs.

registration_responses.q17: These hypotheses will be tested using OLS with and without controls, simple differences in means, and difference of means of sub-groups of the survey respondents.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: It has often been observed that states and nations emerge strengthened from episodes of violence, but the exact reasons for this remain moot. Classic theories argue that war can foster the selection of capable forms of military organization, and ratchet up state involvement in the economy (Tilly 1975, 1990; Mann 1986; Herbst 1990; North, Wallis, and Weingast 2009). Others have stressed the nation-building effect of socialization in the military (Weber 1976; Hobsbawm 1983). Adding to these established theories, we formulate and test the hypothesis that experiences of violence can strengthen the legitimacy of the state, and can increase citizen engagement. The theory we are proposing is simple: the experience of violence makes clear the power of politics in private affairs, and the necessity for collective defense, which, in turn, can only be provided by a functioning state. Victims of violence place a greater emphasis on citizen’s duties, but also hold their representatives to account to a greater degree. Realizing that corruption and bad governance ultimately threaten their own security, victims are more likely to demand the removal of corrupt and incompetent politicians. We aim to test our theory on a random sample of n=2,500 Armenian citizens. Armenia offers a crucial test for the theory. According to estimates, about half of the Armenian population had family members killed during the Armenian genocide in the early 20th century, and thus has family memories of violence. In addition, Armenia fought a fierce war with Azerbaijan over the region of Nagorno Karabakh in the early 1990s. The war claimed several thousand victims, meaning that many families in contemporary Armenia have recently lost relatives in warfare. We exploit these two sources of variation in victimization in mass violence to test our theory. We hypothesize that individuals whose families have been directly affected by violence are more concerned about security, more strongly aware of the effect politics can have on them, consider the state as more legitimate, and are more strongly opposed to corruption.

q16.value: H1: State awareness and legitimacy is higher among victims of current or historical violence H2: Victims of current and historical violence score higher on the political activism scale

q17.value: We test these hypotheses by regressing our outcome scales on the treatment indicators and the specified control variables using OLS

According to estimates, about half of the Armenian population had family members killed during the Armenian genocide in the early 20th century, and thus has family memories of violence. attributes.title: Intent, Race, and American Public Concern for Wartime Civilian Harm

q1.value: Intent, Race, and American Public Concern for Wartime Civilian Harm

q5.value: For their helpful comments at various stages of the project, I am grateful to Michael Allen, Matthew Evangelista, Sarah Kreps, Sarah Maxey, and Joseph Margulies.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Recent scholarship in International Relations has found that wartime civilian harm by the U.S. military reduces American public support for the use of force. These scholars have largely attributed public concern for civilian harm to the internalization and legitimacy of international legal principles that proscribe harm to noncombatants in military conflicts—the “international law mechanism” (Kreps and Wallace 2016; Chilton 2015; Sikkink 2011; Simmons 2009; Finnemore and Sikkink 1998). However, scholars have not examined whether public concern for civilian harm is a result of moral considerations that are independent of international law. I put forth an alternative mechanism rooted in recent research in moral psychology that finds humans are intuitively sensitive to the intent behind harm to innocents, in particular the distinction between intentional, foreseeable but unintentional, and accidental harm (e.g Mikhail 2011). Using a survey experiment, I will test whether the “morality mechanism” or the “international law mechanism” best explains public concern for the intent behind the U.S. military’s harm to civilians. I also investigate whether or not in-group biases influence public support for the use of force. In particular, I examine whether or not public support for wartime civilian harm is impacted by implicit normative cues that military members transmit through their actions in combat.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1 (international law mechanism): Due to the internalization of the noncombatant immunity norm, public support for the use of force decreases as civilian harm shifts from accidental to foreseeable to intentional. Hypothesis 2 (morality mechanism): Due to moral considerations independent of international law, public support for the use of force decreases as civilian harm shifts from accidental to foreseeable to intentional. Hypothesis 3 (moral cue-taking): The public moderates its attitudes towards the morality of wartime civilian harm by implicit normative information from U.S. military members.

q17.value: To investigate these hypotheses, I will conduct a novel experiment that tests public reactions to civilian harm in which international law conflicts with morality. The scenario is based on a real-world dilemma that Paul Scharre, a former Army ranger, and his sniper team encountered in Afghanistan, in which they made a moral decision to be evacuated from the field rather than lawfully kill a young girl scouting for the Taliban (Scharre 2018). The experiment will test whether respondents support the lawful killing of a young girl by American snipers in a counter-terrorism operation. The experiment will have a 4x2 factorial design. Treatments 1-2: In the intentional treatment, the soldiers must decide whether or not to intentionally target a young girl who is scouting for the Taliban. The second treatment will replace the young girl with a man scouting for the Taliban. Treatment 3: In the foreseeable treatment, the snipers must decide whether or not to target a man who is scouting for the Taliban, anticipating that a nearby young girl will be killed. Treatment 4: In the accidental treatment, the snipers must decide whether or not to target the man scouting for the Taliban, not anticipating that the girl will be killed. Respondents will be asked if the soldiers should (1) kill the scout or (2) radio their base to be removed from the field. Afterwards, respondents will be randomly assigned to one of two treatments in which they are informed the soldiers killed the scout (along with the civilian in treatments 3 and 4) or decided to be removed from the field. The experiment offers a direct test of hypotheses 1-4. Statistically significant differences in support for killing the scout across the intent treatments would constitute strong evidence for the morality mechanism, given that international law sanctions killing the girl. The secondary treatments will measure the extent to which respondents’ attitudes are influenced by the actions the soldiers decided to take.

registration_responses.q1: Intent, Race, and American Public Concern for Wartime Civilian Harm
registration_responses.q5: For their helpful comments at various stages of the project, I am grateful to Michael Allen, Matthew Evangelista, Sarah Kreps, Sarah Maxey, and Joseph Margulies.

attributes.title: Voting behavior along the revolutionary path

q1.value: Voting behavior along the revolutionary path

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Political leaders throughout modern history have used the technique of the `march' as a tool to mobilize supporters (Salisbury 1985; Weber 2002; Broers 2014). But does this tactic work? We study a unique natural experiment from Armenia that allows us to address this question. In spring 2018, Nikol Pashinyan, the main opposition leader, led a two-week march towards the country's capital Yerevan to mobilize the population against the prolongation of the autocratically ruling president, Serzh Sargsyan (Figure 1). In the wake of the march, thousands of Pashinyan's supporters started protesting in cities and towns across the country. We asked to what extent the march was successful in mobilizing voters. Were individuals that lived along the route of the march more likely to subsequently cast their vote, and did they vote for the revolutionary? To answer these questions, we draw on three data sources: first, we use election outcome data on the precinct level for the general elections to take place on 9 December 2018. Second, we use answers to a survey conducted among a random, nationally-representative sample of 2,500 Armenians shortly before the general elections. Third, we hand-collected and examined election records for all our respondents. We are therefore able to determine turnout in an objective fashion, rather than relying on voter self- reports. With this data, we test the hypothesis that the march i) mobilized voters to turn out at higher numbers, and ii) vote for Pashinyan’s ‘My Step’ alliance at higher rates. We further test the hypothesis that the effect partly works through increasing political efficacy in the electorate.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1: Individuals living closer to the path of the march are mobilized. Hypothesis 2: Precincts closer to the path of the march have a higher turnout; individuals living closer to the path turn out at higher numbers.

q17.value: Most hypotheses are tested straightforwardly using OLS or Probit regressions of the variable of interest on the regressor of interest and the number of controls (individual characteristics). The detailed description of the way variables are constructed and which regression are planned to be run available in PAP.
